text: I don’t follow her out. The moment the door closes, I regret it—but I slide the bolt in deeper anyway, like I’m wrestling with my own impulse.
The hearth flickers. I stare at the flame, trying to convince myself: she doesn’t need me. She never has.
But the silence is unbearable. Every crack of burning wood sounds like distant combat; every gust of wind like someone pausing outside the door.
I stand, sit, stand again. I wipe the table three times. I realign the glasses to the same exact angle.
I don’t know what I’m waiting for—until I hear soft footsteps on the stairs.
The steps are steady. Familiar. Like someone who’s walked this path a hundred times.
Alicia steps out from the stairwell shadows. Snow clings to the edge of her cloak. There’s a fresh cut across her knuckles.
She doesn’t look at me—as if eye contact would invite unnecessary emotion.
“You’re back.”
“Mm.”
She tosses something onto the counter. The metal striking wood is soft—but it tightens my chest.
It’s a ring-shaped token, its edge scorched like it was torn straight from fire.
“That’s… the Echo Circle’s?”
“Their mark.”
“I paid them a visit. Saves them from trying their usual tricks.”
She says it like it’s nothing—but her shoulders are visibly tense. The fatigue of someone who’s been holding herself upright too long.
“Annoying, honestly.”
“You went alone again?”
She finally looks at me. There’s no reproach—just that steady calm that says don’t complicate this.
“You staying here was right.”
“If you came, I’d have to split my focus protecting you.”
She pauses—swallowing something more direct.
“I don’t want another variable.”
She nudges the token closer. Her fingers tremble faintly. She pulls her hand back immediately, like she doesn’t want me to notice.
“You’re hurt.”
“Small cut.”
“Don’t ask about the rest.”
She adjusts her cloak over her shoulders, like hiding the scent of blood along with the wound.
“I’ll handle the Echo Circle line.”
“You just guard the inn. Guard yourself.”
Only after saying that does her breathing settle back into her chest.
She takes the token and turns toward the stairs.
“You’re going out again tomorrow?”
“Tomorrow’s the final round.”
“It’s not over yet.”
At the foot of the stairs, she stops—like she’s finally allowed herself to exhale a fraction.
“You did well tonight.”
It isn’t praise. It’s confirmation: you’re alive—and you weren’t pulled into it.
